entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration(CI/CPI) Automated iFlow Comparison and Summarization Using Generative AI
entry.content:
When multiple teams collaborate on the same SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI) iFlow, changes can pile up quickly and it becomes difficult to pinpoint what was altered, who changed it, and which modifications must be transported to higher environments. To solve this, I built sapci_iflow_compare, a lightweight Streamlit app that fetches two iFlow XMLs and generates a technical, element-level diff, with an optional AI summary to make the results easy to review.

This blog walks through what the tool does and how to run it. It also explains why not to upload iFlow XMLs directly to public chatbots and how this approach keeps your content safer.

What the Solution Does

  • Connects to CI/CPI design‚Äëtime via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts to retrieve the selected iFlow‚Äôs ZIP and extract the .iflw XML for comparison (or accepts two local .iflw files) 
  • Matches nodes by id and performs a recursive comparison (attributes, text, structure), ignoring order differences where relevant, to produce a precise, developer‚Äëfriendly diff.
  • Displays the raw technical diff and (optionally) sends only the minimized difference report to Gemini for a human‚Äëreadable summary; you can disable the AI step entirely for strict confidentiality.

Architecture Overview

  • Inputs

Two CI/CPI design‚Äëtime endpoints (OAuth client credentials), or two local .iflw XMLs

 

  • API & Extraction

Calls /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts on your tenant to fetch the artifact content (ZIP) and extract the .iflw XML. 

 

  • Diff Engine

Parses both XMLs and generates an element‚Äëlevel diff with attribute and text changes. 

 

  • Optional AI Summary

Sends only the diff to Gemini for summarization, not the entire iFlow XML, keeping exposure to a minimum

Connectivity & Security: Fetching iFlow XMLs via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts

The tool connects to design‚Äëtime using the Integration Content OData API (OData V2), specifically the IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts resource exposed on SAP API Business Hub. This API supports downloading design‚Äëtime artifacts

Endpoint Pattern

  • Tenant base URL (design‚Äëtime):
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com
  • Resource path:
    /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Typical call:
    GET /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='<ArtifactId>',Version='<ArtifactVersion>')/$value
    (Exact resource and operations are documented in the API reference.) [api.sap.com]

Authentication

Use OAuth2 Client Credentials against your XSUAA token endpoint to obtain an access token, then call the API with that token. SAP‚Äôs help portal details roles and inbound HTTP client setup for Integration Content OData API access

Option A: Configure credentials in config_file.json

If your policy permits, store per‚Äëenvironment client credentials in the app‚Äôs JSON:

{
    "api1": {
      "name": "Source iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://source-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://source-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "source-client-id",
      "client_secret": "source-client-secret"
    },
    "api2": {
      "name": "Target iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://target-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://target-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "target-client-id",
      "client_secret": "target-client-secret"
    },
    "gemini_api_url": "https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent",
    "gemini_api_key": "your-gemini-api-key"
  }
This uses the design‚Äëtime OData endpoint documented by SAP and the standard client‚Äëcredentials grant for server‚Äëto‚Äëserver integration.
 

Option B: Enter credentials at runtime in Streamlit

If storing secrets locally is a security concern, leave the client_id and client_secret blank in the config and enter them at runtime in the Streamlit UI. The app holds them in memory for the session and does not write them to disk. You‚Äôll input:

  • Tenant API URL:
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Token URL: https://<your-xsuaa-domain>/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: entered interactively in the UI

This approach adheres to the principle of minimizing persistence of credentials while leveraging the same SAP OData API

Setup & Run

  • Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare.git
cd sapci_iflow_compare
  • Install dependencies
pip3 install streamlit lxml requests
  • Choose your credential mode

Option A: Fill config_file.json with client credentials per environment.

Option B: Leave secrets empty and enter them at runtime via UI (recommended if local storage of secrets is not permitted).
(Both use the same SAP design‚Äëtime API.)

  • Run the app
python3 -m streamlit run iflow_compare.py
  • Click Compare iFlows to fetch, extract, and compare the two iFlow XMLs. Review the Raw Technical Diff and, if enabled, the AI Summary

Testing

  • I will use the Visual Studio code to run the .py file

  • Run the command

  • Page is opened in the browser as below and for simplicity, I will use Option A, using Config file, provide the config file path and click on compare iFlows

  • You can see the detailed differences of iFlow_1 and iFlow_2. If needed, it can be downloaded for detailed analysis

  • If needed, raw differences can be sent to Google Gemini and get the summary in readable format

This is just an idea and both difference logic and prompt can be extended as per the requirement

Recommended Use Cases

  1. Pre‚Äëtransport gate check
    Run a compare just before transport and attach the diff to your change ticket which mirrors best practice in community tools that emphasize confirming intended changes prior to moving artifacts. 

  2. Detect drift across packages/tenants
    Particularly useful when DEV and TEST coexist on the same tenant and packages fall out of sync is an issue documented by practitioners.

  3. Git workflows & automation
    Combine with GitHub sync (e.g., FlashPipe) and run the compare in a CI job or GitHub Action to block unintended changes on a pull request

Security: Why You Should Not Upload Full iFlow XMLs to Public Chatbots

Uploading raw iFlow XMLs (which may include endpoints, headers, and process logic) to public chatbots is risky:

  • Data training & retention: Public chatbot plans may use prompts to improve models and retain conversations (~30 days) even when training is disabled, which can violate internal policies for confidential data. (Enterprise plans have stronger guarantees, but that requires organizational adoption.) 

  • Real‚Äëworld incidents: Multiple organizations have restricted public chatbots after employees accidentally pasted confidential source code or internal materials; these cases underscore the leakage risk even when intentions are benign. 

  • SAP‚Äôs own caution: CI/CPI warns that placing sensitive values in headers or properties risks accidental exposure. Sending entire iFlow models externally increases that exposure surface. 

  • Safer pattern: Do your local comparison and, if you use AI, submit only a redacted difference report (no full iFlow XML) to your AI service or disable AI entirely. That is exactly how sapci_iflow_compare is designed

Conclusion

sapci_iflow_compare provides a repeatable, secure, and developer‚Äëfriendly way to compare iFlow changes across environments without exposing full iFlow XMLs to public chatbots. Whether you are preparing a transport, auditing changes, or reviewing a pull request, the element‚Äëlevel diff and optional readable summary help you move faster with confidence. As conveyed previously, this is an idea which can be extended as per your requirements.

  • GitHub: Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare

Please try it out, share feedback, and help improve the SAP integration ecosystem!

entry.title: Re: Requirement for Automatic Quotation Upload via Email
entry.content:
Good day @PRANAV-KUMAR 

Thank you for your question.

To summarise, you cannot directly upload quotation from email into F1991 in public cloud. You can achieve that by:

  • Entering it manually,
  • integrating it from SAP Business Network/Ariba (Quote Automation/Sourcing), or
  • Using APIs to call your Supplier quotations from an external or BTP based solution.

Here is a link for some details: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/b6e67357efb1a86be10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

If you must start your process from email, you will need a custom BTP based email and document extraction flow that will create quotations through the standard APIs.

If you are open to portal-based collaboration, the recommended standard design is to integrate with SAP Business Network and let supplier submit quotes there, which will then flow automatically into manage supplier quotations.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - CDS Views Equivalent to On-Pre...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

There are multiple options on how you can find the CDS Views.

1.  via CDS Views Documentation

LINK -> https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/ee6ff9b281d8448f96b4fe6c89f2bdc8/5418de55938d1d22e10000000a44147b.html?locale=en-US

2. Visit the SAP Business Accelerator Hub and choose CDS Views from the Categories section. Within the Packages section of the CDS views screen, you can get a complete collection of CDS views tailored to various business areas within SAP S/4HANA.

LINK -> https://api.sap.com/content-type/CDSViews/onstackextensibility/cdsviews

3. Via Fiori View Browser app allows you to:

  • Search for released CDS Views available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.
  • Identify data sources used by a CDS View (its underlying tables or other views).
  • See fields, associations, annotations, and usage.
  • Export a CDS View structure.

To get a list of all available CDS views, use the View Browser app.

One practical way to find the CDS View that replaces an on-premise table is by using the Fiori App: View Browser. (more information here https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/6b356c79dea443c4bbeeaf0865e04207/0bde695751505c08e10000000a441470.html?locale=en-US )

 

Below you can see how you can check the CDS views is in Fiori App View Browser.

1. Open the View Browser App

  1. Log into the Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Use the search bar to look for ‚ÄúView Browser.‚Äù
  3. Open the application.

 

2. Use the ‚ÄúAlternative Search‚Äù Function

At the top of the screen, instead of searching for a CDS view name, click Alternative Search. This feature allows you to search inside the metadata of CDS views ‚Äî including references to classical tables from the on-premise environment.

 

3. Configure the Search Options

In the popup window, choose the following settings:

  • Search In: Table & Column Names
  • Keyword: enter the on-premise table name you want to replace (Examples: KNB1, VBRK etc.)
  • Enable: Table Names
  • Click Search

 

4. Example: Searching for Table KNB1

When you search for KNB1, the system returns the CDS view: I_CustomerCompany

This tells you that:

  • I_CustomerCompany is mapped to the classical table KNB1
  • It belongs to the LO-MD-BP application component (Master Data ‚Äì Business Partner)
  • It is marked as Released, meaning it is safe to use and officially supported
  • It represents customer/company-code master data ‚Äî exactly what KNB1 stored in on-premise systems

 

5. Exploring the CDS View Details

Once you click on the CDS view (in this case, I_CustomerCompany), you can see several important sections that prove its relationship to the old table.

A. Definition Tab

This tab lists all the fields available in the CDS view, such as:

  • Customer (KUNNR)
  • CompanyCode (BUKRS)
  • ReconciliationAccount (AKONT)
  • AccountingClerk (BUSAB)

You will notice that these fields correspond directly to the fields stored in KNB1.

C. Cross Reference Tab

This tab shows all objects (tables, CDS Views, associations) related to the view. At the top, you will see: KNB1.

You also see additional Associations to other CDS views, such as:

  • I_Customer
  • I_CompanyCode
  • I_CustomerDunning
  • I_PaymentBlockingReason

Using the View Browser with Alternative Search allows you to identify which CDS Views replace classical on-premise tables.

 

Now let's check for the other tables. 

  • Table VBAP

 Additionally check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/abf7dc3d11d24976b77c1e78fe24b8a8.html?locale=en-US

 

 

  • Table VBRK

Additionally check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/116ddcc5a4f244a1a138c4a8146f8dc9.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBRP

IMPORTANT! Check link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/2485c474abf344b8b25756b29ac18c1a.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBAK

Additionally check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/955a323799624bd79221780675ada090.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBPA

IMPORTANT! Check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/faa38d278eb3489693e02d5fcfb7ddd1.html?locale=en-US

 

  • Table VBKD

VBKD in classic table ECC is replaced in S4 by table ACDOCA.

Check below links for additional information:

 https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/new-data-architecture-in-sap-fi-on-s-4hana-cloud-what-every-functional/ba-p/14129021

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13545279

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13544498

 

  • Table BKPF

BKPF in classic table ECC is replaced in S4 by table ACDOCA.

Check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/bc3ccd578b90a856e10000000a44147b.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2602.VAL&q=journal%20entry

 

  • Table BSID

BSID in classic table ECC is replaced in S4 by table ACDOCA.

Please check SAP NOTE https://me.sap.com/notes/0003596250

Check link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/ee6ff9b281d8448f96b4fe6c89f2bdc8/47dce95760521070e10000000a44147b.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2025.000&q=ACDOCA

Or link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/f585d657f8a28a3de10000000a441470.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2602.VAL

 

Check below links for additional information:

Link -  https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/new-data-architecture-in-sap-fi-on-s-4hana-cloud-what-every-functional/ba-p/14129021

Link - https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13545279

Link -  https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/all-you-need-to-know-about-universal-journal-acdoca-sap-s-4-hana-2020/ba-p/13544498

 

 

Helpful additional documentations

Finding the right CDS Extractor in SAP S/4HANA

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/finding-the-right-cds-extractor-in-sap-s-4hana/ba-p/13521296

Discover CDS View Based Extractors from SAP S/4HANA Cloud

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/discover-cds-view-based-extractors-from-sap-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13391593

entry.title: Querying RDF Graphs with SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph Engine
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs multi-model platform brings together vector, graph, text, spatial, and relational data natively. It enables developers and data teams to build smarter, more context-aware AI solutions ‚Äî directly on operational data.

SAP HANA Cloud uniquely supports:

  • Vector data for semantic and similarity search
  • Graph data for explicit relationship modeling and knowledge graphs
  • Text and spatial data for real-world context
  • Relational data for structured operations and analytics

Rather than sending data across disparate services, you can store and process all of it in one place, accelerating time-to-value while reducing the risk of misalignment. This is multi-model done right, and it is the foundation for powerful AI workloads that scale.

This blog demonstrates how to query RDF knowledge graphs in SAP HANA Cloud, both:

  • Directly from the HANA Cloud Central SQL Console, and
  • Programmatically using Python

We will also show how RDF graphs can be combined seamlessly with vector similarity search, spatial filtering, and SQL analytics to create intelligent, real‚Äëworld use cases. The blog expands on this post.

From supplier notes to AI‚Äëready supply‚Äëchain intelligence

To ground the concepts, we start with a simple but realistic scenario: turning unstructured supplier feedback into AI‚Äëready supply‚Äëchain intelligence.

Step 1: Create a supply‚Äëchain schema and table

We first create a dedicated schema and table to store supplier identifiers, short operational reports, vector embeddings, and geographic locations.

CREATE SCHEMA KG_SUPPLYCHAIN;

CREATE TABLE KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP (
  supplier_uri       NVARCHAR(200),
  report_text        NVARCHAR(1000),
  report_embedding   REAL_VECTOR(768),
  geo_location       ST_POINT(4326)
);

Step 2: Insert natural‚Äëlanguage supplier reports

The reports represent real‚Äëworld observations such as customs delays or smooth clearance. At this stage, AI embeddings and spatial attributes are not yet populated.

INSERT INTO KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP VALUES
('http://example.org/supplier/AlphaGmbH', 'Consistently on time. No customs issue.', NULL, NULL),
('http://example.org/supplier/BetaGmbH',  'Severe customs delays reported last month.', NULL, NULL),
('http://example.org/supplier/GammaLogistics', 'Smooth operations, cleared customs quickly.', NULL, NULL);

Step 3: Add geographic context

Each supplier is enriched with a geographic location using WGS84 coordinates. This enables proximity analysis and regional risk assessment.

UPDATE KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP
SET geo_location = ST_GeomFromText('POINT(8.6821 50.1109)', 4326)
WHERE supplier_uri = 'http://example.org/supplier/AlphaGmbH';

Step 4: Generate vector embeddings inside the database

SAP HANA Cloud generates vector embeddings directly in‚Äëdatabase using SAP‚Äôs native embedding model. This enables semantic understanding of supplier reports.

UPDATE KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP
SET report_embedding = VECTOR_EMBEDDING(
  report_text,
  'QUERY',
  'SAP_NEB.20240715'
);

At this point, we have a single AI‚Äëready table that supports:

  • Semantic similarity search
  • Spatial analysis
  • Generative AI grounding

‚Äîall without exporting data outside SAP HANA Cloud.

Adding semantic supplier knowledge with SAP HANA Knowledge Graph

Relational tables capture operational facts well, but business meaning and rules are better expressed semantically. This is where the SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph engine comes in.

Step 5: Initialize the RDF graph

We start by removing any existing graph to ensure a clean load.

CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE('DROP GRAPH <kg_supplychain>', '', ?, ?);

Step 6: Insert semantic supplier knowledge

We then insert RDF triples describing suppliers and their business attributes. Each supplier uses the same URI as the relational table, creating a natural bridge between SQL and RDF.

CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE(
'
INSERT DATA {
  GRAPH <kg_supplychain> {
    <http://example.org/supplier/AlphaGmbH> a <Supplier> ;
      <hasCertification> "ISO 9001" ;
      <hasCarbonTaxRate> "low" ;
      <isFlaggedForDelays> false .
  }
}',
'', ?, ?);

Within the Knowledge Graph, suppliers are enriched with structured, machine‚Äëreadable facts such as certifications, carbon‚Äëtax exposure, and compliance flags.

The result is a dual‚Äëlayer architecture:

  • Relational layer: text, embeddings, spatial data
  • Semantic layer: business meaning, rules, and relationships

Both are connected by shared URIs and executed in the same database.

Querying across graph, vector, spatial, and SQL models

Query 1: Filter Knowledge Graph data directly in SQL

SAP HANA Cloud allows SPARQL queries to be consumed as relational tables using SPARQL_TABLE, enabling seamless integration with SQL analytics.

SELECT * FROM SPARQL_TABLE('
  SELECT ?supplier ?certification ?carbontax ?flag
  FROM <kg_supplychain>
  WHERE {
    ?supplier a <Supplier> .
    ?supplier <hasCertification> ?certification .
    ?supplier <hasCarbonTaxRate> ?carbontax .
    ?supplier <isFlaggedForDelays> ?flag .
    FILTER(
      ?certification = "ISO 9001" &&
      ?carbontax = "low" &&
      STR(?flag) = "false"
    )
  }
');

This bridges semantic reasoning and relational analytics in a single query flow.

Query 2: Hybrid SPARQL + SQL with vector and spatial filtering

This advanced query combines:

  1. Geospatial filtering (nearby suppliers)
  2. Vector similarity search on supplier reports
  3. Knowledge Graph constraints

CALL SPARQL_EXECUTE(
'
SELECT *
FROM <kg_supplychain>
WHERE {
  SQL_TABLE("SELECT \"uri_str\", \"REPORT_TEXT\", \"SCO\" FROM (
    SELECT *, sco - FIRST_VALUE(sco) OVER(ORDER BY sco DESC) AS diff
    FROM (
      SELECT \"SUPPLIER_URI\" AS \"uri_str\", \"REPORT_TEXT\",
      COSINE_SIMILARITY(
        \"REPORT_EMBEDDING\",
        VECTOR_EMBEDDING(''no customs delay'', ''QUERY'', ''SAP_NEB.20240715'')
      ) AS sco
      FROM KG_SUPPLYCHAIN.SUPPLIER_REPORTS_LOOKUP
      WHERE \"GEO_LOCATION\".ST_Distance(
        ST_GeomFromText(''POINT(8.6821 50.1109)'', 4326)
      ) < 50000
      ORDER BY sco DESC
    )
  ) WHERE diff > -0.2") .
}
ORDER BY DESC(?SCO)
LIMIT 10
',
'Accept: application/sparql-results+csv Content-Type: application/sparql-query',
?, ?);

This single query performs AI‚Äëdriven supplier discovery, ranking results by semantic meaning while respecting spatial and business rules.

Querying and managing Knowledge Graphs with Python

Beyond the SQL console, Knowledge Graphs can be managed programmatically using Python and the HANA DBAPI.

The following example shows how to:

  • Upload an RDF ontology (Turtle .ttl format)
  • Verify graph load success
  • Query RDF data programmatically
from hdbcli import dbapi

conn = dbapi.connect(
    address='XXX.hana.prod-ap10.hanacloud.ondemand.com',
    port=443,
    user='XXX',
    password='XXX'
)

cursor = conn.cursor()

Load an ontology into SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph

# Populate a new RDF in HANA Cloud with the turtle file content. We put the ontology into a specific graph.
ttl_filename = "/Users/materials_ontology.ttl"
graph_name = "materials_ontology"

# Load the ontology into HANA Cloud KG
print("Loading ontology...")

try:
    with open(ttl_filename, 'r') as ttlfp:
        request_hdrs = ''
        request_hdrs += 'rqx-load-protocol: true' + '\r\n'            # required header for upload protocol
        request_hdrs += 'rqx-load-filename: ' + ttl_filename + '\r\n' # optional header
        request_hdrs += 'rqx-load-graphname: ' + graph_name + '\r\n'   # optional header to specify name of the graph
        
        print(f"Loading file: {ttl_filename}")
        print(f"Graph name: {graph_name}")
        
        # Execute the load
        result = conn.cursor().callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (ttlfp.read(), request_hdrs, '?', None))
        print("Materials ontology loaded successfully!")
        print(f"Result: {result}")
        
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error loading materials ontology: {e}")
    print(f"Error type: {type(e)}")

Query the ontology 

Do note that you will have to adjust the query based on your ontology structure.

# Verify the materials ontology was loaded
print("Verifying materials ontology load...")

try:
    # Count triples in the materials graph
    query = f"""
    SELECT (COUNT(*) as ?Triples) 
    WHERE 
      {{ GRAPH <{graph_name}> 
          {{ ?s ?p ?o }} 
      }}
    """
    
    resp = conn.cursor().callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (query, 'Accept: application/sparql-results+csv', '?', None))
    print("Materials ontology statistics:")
    print(resp[2])
    
    # Query for some material instances
    query2 = f"""
    PREFIX mat: <http://example.com/materials/>
    PREFIX matprop: <http://example.com/materials/property/>
    
    SELECT ?material ?materialId ?level2 ?level3
    FROM <{graph_name}>
    WHERE {{
        ?material a mat:Material .
        ?material matprop:materialId ?materialId .
        OPTIONAL {{ ?material matprop:level2 ?level2 . }}
        OPTIONAL {{ ?material matprop:level3 ?level3 . }}
    }}
    LIMIT 5
    """
    
    resp2 = conn.cursor().callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (query2, 'Accept: application/sparql-results+csv', '?', None))
    print("\n Sample material instances:")
    print(resp2[2])
    
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error verifying materials ontology: {e}")

Summary

SAP HANA Cloud enables true multi‚Äëmodel intelligence by allowing relational data, vector embeddings, spatial context, and RDF knowledge graphs to coexist and execute together.

By combining in‚Äëdatabase vector embeddings, semantic Knowledge Graphs, and SQL, SPARQL, Python access, organizations can build powerful AI applications that are context‚Äëaware, explainable, and operationally grounded‚Äîall from a single platform.

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database for AI. It is where data, meaning, and intelligence converge.

entry.title: Master Cloud Customer Agreement Enrollment (MCCA) in SAP for Me!
entry.content:
SAP now offers a convenient self-service feature for corporate customers: request your Master Cloud Customer Agreement (MCCA) directly through SAP for Me. This streamlined process separates MCCA signing from commercial negotiations, allowing you to review and sign the agreement at your convenience.

With the intuitive MCCA card available in the Finance & Legal Dashboard, you are guided through a simple three-step process: review a legal disclaimer, enter your signatory details, and select your preferred language. Once submitted, the MCCA document will be delivered via DocuSign‚Äôs secure website for review and signature.

Take advantage of this new capability to accelerate your cloud contracting journey and ensure a smoother, more flexible experience with SAP.

What is the Master Cloud Customer Agreement?  

The Master Cloud Customer Agreement (MCCA) is SAP‚Äôs standard Terms & Conditions that apply across most of SAP's Cloud portfolio available as a simple Frame Agreement enrollment, making it easier for customers to engage with SAP‚Äôs cloud offerings. For more information on the enrollment procedure and full details on MCCA, please refer to this Knowledgebase Article.

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - How to handle ERP connection mapping...
entry.content:
1. Does SAP Datasphere automatically detect and remap the connection from DIX ‚Üí QIX during import?
-> No SAP don't have it 
2. If not, is there any connection mapping mechanism similar to BDLS (logical system mapping) in SAP BW?
-> No SAP don't have it 
3. Is it possible to maintain a mapping configuration file (e.g., JSON) for connection replacement during import via CTMS?|
-> No SAP don't have it 
Ans:

Align the Logic

Use a consistent naming convention for Connection Name:
Example:

DEV subaccount ‚Üí contains SAP Datasphere connected to the ERP DEV system (connection name: DIX)

QAS subaccount ‚Üí contains SAP Datasphere connected to the ERP QAS system (connection name: QIX)
Because the connection name cannot be changed after it is transported to DSP QA/PRD tenants.

Different S/4 Environments

Keep the same connection name but point it to different backend systems.
‚Üí When this connection is imported into the corresponding DSP environment, you must manually update the configuration so it points to the correct S/4 environment.
(Note during deployment ‚Üí carefully verify the connection after updating the configuration), and only then trigger the data load ‚Üí (to ensure data security).

Deployment Notes
-- The Technical Name cannot be changed after creation.
-- The connection must be placed in the appropriate package.
-- After creation, the connection must be tested/validated.

Related Configurations
-- It is recommended to standardize the naming of Space IDs.
-- You may use multiple datastores to support multi-environment development.
-- Consider the IP Allowlist for each environment.

entry.title: Manufacturing Dates Report for Unitized Materials in SAP PEO
entry.content:
[Blog Type: Hands-on Expertise]

 

Summary

This blog post describes an approach to how to implement in SAP S/4HANA a progress report containing the planned and actual production dates at every assembly step (section-material, position-operation) for every model-unit of a project. This report is crucial for planners and rest of the organization, giving visibility about the dates/status of the different complex products while moving on the shop floor.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on production engineering and operations within SAP S/4HANA.

 

Introduction

Complex product structures in SAP S/4HANA are managed with a combination of Project System (PS) and Production Engineering and Operations (PEO). Complex assembly industries use model-unit effectivity to control the configuration of an assembly product. PEO uses classical parameter effectivity in Engineering Change Management (ECM) to implement model-unit effectivity, what is known as product unitization.

Product unitization is a mechanism of managing multiple configurations of an assembly and its production process plan (routing) in a way that all the possible units can be modeled using the same super bill of material and super routing. When a particular unit is to be produced, the super bill of material and related super routing are filtered to retrieve only the information relevant for that unit and assigned to the production order.

You can use materials of different types to model the assemblies used in complex assembly manufacturing:

  • An End Item (EI) represents the final product, i.e. a complete aircraft, which is often not represented by a single BOM, but by a set of BOMs, i.e. major assemblies.
  • A Major Assembly (MA) is unitized, i.e. configurable and represents a large section of the product such as a wing or center fuselage section.
  • An Installation Kit (IK) is an organizational breakdown of the major assembly. An IK represents the work content, which can be handled, for example, in one shift.

Image 1. Complex product structure in SAP S/4HANA.

The image below depicts an example of a manufacturing layout for assembling a complex product.

Image 2. Example of manufacturing layout for assembling complex products.

Imaging a complex product which consists of 4 parts lists, and consequently 4 routings. This means that routing is created for each line segment/section of the production process. This is a mechanism to ensure the flexibility of the planning. Whether having an independent order or just an operation/position of the overall order will depend on when to establish sequence changes between positions.

Typically, the complex product goes through several positions on the line until its complete. For example, the second line section on the image has a total of 6 positions. The installation processes which take place on every position are referred as an installation kit. The underlying routing serves only to coordinate installation activities and thus do not represent executable routings. This means the line work centers are only for orchestration, as the actual work is always done on the installation work centers.

For example, on section 2 of line 1 the product can stay 3 days on one position until the move to the next position, while on same section of line 2 the product stays 4 days on one position. This means line 1 is faster than line 2, for example, because on line 1 the fastest people work. The time that passes until all products are moved by one position is called the takt time. Takt time duration is defined in the routing. The bottleneck work centers are crucial for the scheduling of each position and detailed scheduling is based on these resources.

Only by having this manufacturing layout you can define and plan that each component is available at the right time, that you have the right workers at the right time, and that you have the right resources at the right time.

To get an overview of the manufacturing dates/status of the different complex products at the different stages, a progress report with the planned and actual production dates for every model-unit is used. This report is critical for having manufacturing visibility for planners and rest of the organization. Below you can find an example of this report on Microsoft Excel.

Image 3. Example of manufacturing dates report on Microsoft Excel.

This blog post describes an implementation approach to this manufacturing dates report in SAP S/4HANA.

 

Requirements of the Manufacturing Dates Report

For a correct orchestration of the whole assembly process for unitized products, planners need to have an overview of the planned and actual dates of the key planning elements of an assembled product with engineering-to-order (ETO) processes. Customer requested to have a report in a similar format to Microsoft Excel, containing all these manufacturing dates for every model and unit belonging to a specific project.

The main requirements of this manufacturing dates report were the following:

  • The report will be related to the upper levels of the complex product structure, where the planning elements are related to operative WBS elements, so no elements managed under the grouping WBS element.
  • The report will only take care of the planning elements under a single configuration level, since the relationship between the different configuration levels elements does not exist. The identification of the configuration level of a model will be done by the assignation of a specific model type (for example, aircraft final assembly, left wing, center fuselage, wheelset).
  • Initially only the internally produced materials will be considered as supply elements for the report. Therefore, only planned orders and production orders will be considered.
  • The report will assume that every model and unit of the configuration level is manufactured/assembled in one single plant.
  • To identify the planning elements relevant for every model-unit, the system will use the effectivity parameters (model and unit) of every planning element.

Image 4. Example of assignation of model type (configuration level) to models.

You must consider that model-unit effectivity can only be used if the material and all its parents are subject to make-to-project planning, that it, the planning elements are related to operative WBS elements.

As customer was using an external project management software tool to manage project planning, the main assumptions about this tool were the following:

  • The tool will send the planned finish date/time for every model-unit of every complex product on the different configuration levels, and this will be done in the network activity material reservations on SAP S/4HANA.
  • The tool will define the planned assembly line for every model-unit, and this will be done in the network activity work center on SAP S/4HANA.

Customer requirement was to have this finish date (‚Äútarget date‚Äù) from the external tool also displayed on the manufacturing dates report, to be able to compare dates from external tool with dates proposed by MRP Live on SAP S/4HANA, and thus verifying alignment or misalignment.

The planned finish date/time coming from the external project tool was also the basis for the scheduling of the orders, together with the takt time. The takt time of the line represents the duration of the operation of the order (whatever process done), and it is defined in the routing. The planned assembly line coming from the external project tool was used to align all the work centers of the pegging tree order operation.

 

Design of the Manufacturing Dates Report

The expected layout of the customer for the manufacturing dates report in SAP S/4HANA was the following:

Image 5. Design of the expected layout for the manufacturing dates report.

The true challenge of this report was to make the report dynamic and able to indicate the relevant planning elements required for every different project, regardless of the configuration level, of the product, of the assembly process and/or the different assembly operations.

This was achieved by creating a configuration tool with the following three levels of configuration, allowing a dynamic column layout visualization:

  1. Level 1 = Layouts level. This level contains the different layouts and the corresponding layout definition and assignation to model type.
  2. Level 2 = Columns level. This level contains the numbered columns where the planning element needs to be placed in the report, and the type of date to be placed for the referenced element. For every column, a column description will be maintained as the alias of the specific assembly process taking place. There are two date types:
    1. Material date: date comes from header dates of planning element.
    2. Operation date: date comes from operation dates of planning element. The operation number in this case is filled on column Operation.
  3. Level 3 = Columns criteria level. This level contains the material/s for which the planning elements and their dates need to be selected for every column.

Image 6. Design of the layout configuration for the manufacturing dates report.

For every model-unit, the report will display three different lines showing different types of dates:

  • Target Dates
  • Plan Dates
  • Real Dates

For every date to be shown, the report will display two different columns, one with the Start Date and the other with the Finish Date of the corresponding planning element.

Target Dates will be the dates defined by Planning Department and coming from the external project management software tool, and they will be defined in the Network Activity Material Reservations (table RESB) in SAP S/4HANA. The date to be shown in the report will correspond to the reservation of every material which appears in the configuration tool of the report. Target dates will only be available for columns where dates are coming from materials. In case dates coming from operations, target dates will be empty. Target dates will only be displayed on the Finish Date column, so that the Start Date column will be leave it empty.

Plan Dates will be the dates defined in SAP S/4HANA because of the planning (MRP Live), that is, the planned dates for a planning element of a given material, plant and WBS element (model-unit). The plant will be a selection screen field of the report. The planned dates will be first determined based on the open planned receipts on the stock/requirements list (module function BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST). If no elements selected in the previous step, then closed planned receipts (finally delivered) will be considered, based on the good movements already completed. The date will be the planned date of the element for which the good receipt has been completed (last good movement executed or with the most recent date). In case dates coming from operations, plan dates will come from corresponding operation planned dates.

Actual Dates will be the real dates of the order execution. The actual dates will be first determined based on the planning elements with material movements (good receipts) for a given material, plant and WBS element (model-unit). If not, based on the posting date (MATDOC-BUDAT) of the good movements already completed (last good movement executed or with the most recent date). In case dates coming from operations, actual dates will come from the real confirmation posting dates of the corresponding operations (first confirmation for Start Date and last confirmation for Finish Date).

 

Realization of the Manufacturing Dates Report

The dynamic configuration of the report layout was achieved by using maintenance cluster technology on three levels. Thereby a configuration cluster (transaction SE54) was created with several configuration tables and three hierarchy levels, as already explained in previous design point (layouts level, columns level, columns criteria level). As the identification of the configuration level for a model is done by the assignation of a specific model type (for example, aircraft final assembly, left wing, center fuselage, wheelset), layouts were uniquely assigned to a specific model type.

Image 7. Example of layout level for the configuration tool.

Image 8. Example of columns level for the configuration tool.

Image 9. Example of columns criteria level for the configuration tool.

The selection screen of the manufacturing dates report was the following:

Image 10. Selection screen of the manufacturing dates report.

By selecting a Model Type, the selection of the Layout ID was restricted (view help) to those assigned to this specific model type. The Plant was also required for fetching the planning elements data at plant level. Either a Project or a WBS Element was also necessary to limit the data to specific project objects. The different Date Types could be displayed or hidden by using the corresponding checkboxes (at least one is required). A Date Range was also mandatory to limit the data fetching of the planning elements to specific time horizon.

An example of the output list for the manufacturing dates report with the previous example of configuration layout is the following:

Image 11. Example of output list for the manufacturing dates report.

Columns with date type ‚ÄúMaterial‚Äù correspond with dates on planning elements for the material/s belonging to the related column criteria.

Image 12. Planning elements for columns with date type ‚ÄúMaterial‚Äù.

Columns with date type ‚ÄúOperation‚Äù match with the related operation numbers of the routing (shop floor routing on PEO):

Image 13. Columns with date type ‚ÄúOperation‚Äù and related operation numbers of the routing.

Below you can display an example of how dates are calculated for one model-unit of a project, when planning elements are planned orders, for the different date types (rows) and the different process steps (columns):

Image 14. Example of calculated dates from planned orders on manufacturing dates report.

As only the internally produced materials were initially considered, plan dates can come from both planned orders and production orders, but actual dates only proceed from production orders. To know how firmed the dates are, the report differentiates dates coming from the different planning elements (and with different status) by using different cell colors, which are the following:

  • Planned Order (white color with text on blue color)
  • Production Order on status Created (blue color)
  • Production Order on status Released (green color)

Image 15. Example of output list with cell color coding for the manufacturing dates report.

Below you can display another example of how dates are calculated for one model-unit of a project, when planning elements are production orders, for the different date types (rows) and the different process steps (columns):

Image 16. Example of calculated dates from production orders on manufacturing dates report.

Finally, a customized data exportation process to Microsoft Excel was also implemented on button ‚ÄúExport Data to Excel‚Äù, to obtain the specific layout requested by the customer.

Image 17. Manufacturing dates report exported to Microsoft Excel.

 

Improvements of the Manufacturing Dates Report

Several improvements were requested after the first version of the manufacturing dates report, as users became aware of missing scenarios or new needs arising from the daily use of the report. The following is a not exhaustive list of these improvements:

1. External Procurement Scenario

Besides planned orders and production orders for the internally produced materials, more planning elements were considered for the report. Planned elements for the externally procured materials were also considered, specifically purchase requisitions and purchase orders (also shipping notifications). Dates coming from these new planning elements were identified by using cell color yellow.

Image 18. Example of output list with cell color coding for the manufacturing dates report.

2. Cross-Plant Scenario

The report was initially considering manufacturing only in one single plant. Thus cross-plant scenario where demand on one plant but manufacturing happens on another plant was missing. Customer requested to also cover this scenario with some assumptions:

  • The production on the other plant will be under the same WBS element, that is, same project, model and unit.
  • There will be only one step per plant.
  • The manufacturing will be at plant level, not at MRP area (storage location) level.

3. Groping WBS Scenario

Users realized that there was a small group of unitized materials displayed on the report for which the dates were empty, and reason was that they were being managed by grouping (PMMO). Customer requested to also cover this scenario, so report was adapted to fetch data at model/unit level for these materials, instead of WBS level.

Image 19. Operative WBS elements vs. Grouping WBS elements

4. Assembly Sequence

For some business units it was possible to stablish an assembly sequence and a relation between the different elements of the main units containing several model/units. This was managed on a configuration table called configuration level relationship. Customer requested to include this info on the manufacturing dates report. Therefore, it was possible to order lines by sequence, thus displaying the assembly sequence with corresponding target/plan/real dates aside.

Image 20. Planned assembly sequence on configuration level relationship table.

Image 21. Example of output list with assembly sequence for the manufacturing dates report.

5. Materials Managed in PP/DS

PP/DS was active for some plants and for some material types and/or groups. Customer requested to get more accurate production dates from PP/DS layer instead of S/4 layer, for those internally procured materials managed in PP/DS, and report was changed accordingly.

 

Variant of the Report for Misalignment between Dates

Users noticed that they did not have a proactive way to check for projects with incorrect dates. They were able to display these misalignments on the report, but this was done going project by project and reviewing the dates one by one.

Customer requested a similar report to easily find misalignments between the planned dates entered by Planning (‚ÄúTarget Date‚Äù) and the planned dates calculated by MRP Live (‚ÄúEnd Plan Date‚Äù) and/or later changed by planners. For this new report, the plant and the material were also required in the output list. This was achieved with a fixed layout by merging the information coming from rows "Target Date" and "Plan Date" in the same line, and then including a new column called ‚ÄúDays‚Äù after the date columns. ‚ÄúDays‚Äù column displayed the difference in days between the End Plan Date and Target Date, corresponding to the same model and unit.

A new checkbox ‚ÄúDisplay only date differences‚Äù was also included on the selection screen, to display only lines where difference exists between target and plan dates, to exclusively focus on misalignments.

Image 22. Example of output list for the manufacturing dates misalignment report.

 

Helpful Links

Product Unitization based on Parameter Effectivity (SAP Help Portal)

Complex Assembly Manufacturing (SAP Help Portal)

 

[Disclaimer: Written by Juan Ventura (LinkedIn). This blog post is written by the author based on his personal experience while working on customers with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. Opinions and views expressed herein are solely my own. Before implementing any solution, you are advised to always do the analysis and adopt a solution for specific business case only if it suits customer requirements and testing is successful.]

entry.title: Choosing the right path to Cloud ERP
entry.content:
For many SAP-using organizations, moving to Cloud ERP is not a question of if but how. And businesses are feeling the pressure. End-of-support for ECC is fast approaching and many of SAP‚Äôs newest innovations are offered only in the Cloud.

Despite the urgency, more than half of SAP users have yet to begin their migration. One of the biggest hurdles is choosing the right path to Cloud ERP.

At first, this might seem like a simple decision between Public Cloud ERP and Private Cloud ERP. Yet, the choice is far more complex. It requires careful consideration of your business priorities, regulatory requirements, and landscape complexity.

Public vs Private

It‚Äôs tempting to view Public Cloud ERP as a one-size-fits-all solution, with limited flexibility. Public Cloud ERP is often described as a standardized, SAP-managed solution with a Clean Core ‚Äì where most customizations move to external platforms like BTP. Private Cloud ERP is seen as the more flexible alternative, particularly for organizations needing to retain legacy customizations.

While there is some truth to that distinction, it oversimplifies the reality for businesses considering shifting to the Cloud. The real difference is less about whether you can customize, but where and how.

In Public Cloud, extensions and customizations, mostly occur outside the core ERP system. Unlike Public Cloud, Private Cloud permits more change to the core ERP system and offers more options that address end-user requirements such as hosting preferences and underlying technology.

The Many Variations of Private Cloud

For larger enterprises, Private Cloud is the likely choice. Yet, that choice is anything but straightforward. Over time, SAP has expanded beyond a single core offering of Private Cloud ERP (formerly RISE), offering numerous options designed to meet distinct needs, whether infrastructure preferences, regulatory compliance, or phased migration timelines.

 

Some examples of Private Cloud include:

  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition: Classic RISE with SAP option and the right choice for many enterprises
  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition Tailored: Contracted options are customized per unique customer requirements. May include contracted coverage for many responsibilities considered customer concerns in the base offering.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Sovereign Cloud: Keeps all data and processing within a particular jurisdiction or geography. It‚Äôs ideal when technical or regulatory requirements make traditional off-site hosting infeasible.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Hyperscaler: Runs on the customer‚Äôs preferred hyperscaler, often leveraging an existing relationship.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Hyperscaler Tailored: Modified version of Cloud ERP running on the customer‚Äôs existing hyperscaler environment. Offers additional flexibility for deployment architecture and may be more suitable for migrating highly integrated or complex existing on-premises implementations.
  • SAP ERP Customer Datacenter Edition: Brings Cloud architecture into a company‚Äôs datacentre when external hosting isn‚Äôt feasible.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition Transition Option: A commercial offering enabling enterprises to commit to Cloud ERP while keeping ECC supported past 2027 and through 2033.

The number of Cloud ERP options can be overwhelming. Yet, it also means you can choose an offering closely aligned with your strategic goals.

Key considerations for your Cloud journey

There are more options available than many SAP-using organizations realize. The best outcomes come from asking the right questions and focusing on what matters most to your business.

  • Customization: Do we have significant existing customizations? How critical are these customizations? Is code going to be retained or modernized? Where does redevelopment or customization take place?
  • Compliance: What compliance or jurisdictional requirements govern where data can reside?
  • Cloud partnership: How important is leveraging an existing hyperscaler contract or infrastructure investment?
  • Timeline: Do we anticipate maintaining ECC beyond standard support timelines, and if so, what transition paths exist?

Look beyond Public and Private and focus on business realities. In this way, you can identify an option that balances flexibility, control, and long-term viability. It means businesses can avoid putting operations and compliance at risk as they migrate to the Cloud.

The Bottom Line

The journey to Cloud ERP is rarely straightforward. No two organizations have the same requirements and goals. What‚Äôs clear is that there is no universal answer. Public Cloud offers speed, standardization, lower total cost of ownership, automatic SAP updates, and scalability. Private Cloud provides flexibility, with choices built to address distinct business challenges.

The right choice depends on aligning your migration strategy with business outcomes. Focus on your requirements and chart a course that ensures your ERP landscape remains a foundation for growth, innovation, and resilience today and in the future.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-12-11?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

Welcome to our year-end edition of the What‚Äôs New series! We‚Äôre excited to share the latest enhancements in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud - SM).

Let‚Äôs dive in! üòä

Note: These newly released enhancements are currently available exclusively in Fast Track mode.

Modeling Screen

New Modeling Design and Features

Remember the modeling function update introduced in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Modeling Update (Join)?

We‚Äôve taken it further!

Now, most of the functions benefit from this enhancement, reducing steps when modeling a function. Instead of expanding a node, simply click the function‚Äôs properties.

Important:

  • This feature isn‚Äôt activated by default. You‚Äôll see a banner in the modeling screen about its availability.
  • If activated, all building blocks (except Rules) can be accessed and configured directly in the function‚Äôs properties panel. For more details, see Function Building Blocks in SAP Help Portal.
  • Ask your SAP PaPM Cloud - SM administrator to activate it via: Menu > Administration > Settings > Optional Feature Settings. For more details, check Optional Features Settings in SAP Help Portal.

Part of the enhancements are: 

  • Selective Copying & Pasting of Fields 

Copy only the fields you need from the Signature section. Select/unselect fields before hitting Copy Nodes button.

Tip: If you don‚Äôt select any fields, all fields will be copied.

  • Field Sequencing 

Rearrange fields easily! Drag and drop between Granularity, Action, and Selection fields for better structure.

Content Management

Better Environment Import and Upload Handling

When importing content with overwrite or running Data Management screen upload previews, you can now run only one task at a time:

  • If an environment import (overwrite) is in progress, upload in Data Management screen is blocked.

  • If Data Management screen upload preview lock is active (15-minute idle timeout), environment import won‚Äôt start.

For more details, check Content Management in SAP Help Portal.

Process Management

Enhanced Notifications for Teams

Stay informed with in-app and email notifications for admins and end-users in Performer or Reviewer teams.

  • Process State Change

Get notified when a process changes from ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù to ‚ÄúDeployed‚Äù.

  • Comment Change

Get notified when comments are added, edited, or deleted in your assigned activities.

Joule

Enhanced Joule Experience

Managing Joule conversations just got smarter!

Users can now rename or delete any Joule conversation through a new context menu available in both the history sidebar and the active chat header.

Here‚Äôs what you can do with the new Joule enhancements:

  • Rename Conversations
    Renaming is simple: select Rename and the conversation title becomes an inline editable field with a 100-character limit. Press Enter or click outside the field to save changes or press Escape to cancel. If something goes wrong, you‚Äôll see a toast notification.

  • Delete Conversations
    Deleting a conversation is just as easy, but with safeguards. When you choose Delete, a confirmation dialog appears to help prevent accidental removal.

  • Instant Availability
    Joule is now available as soon as you open a report. The system automatically saves it in the background, so you can start using Joule without any extra steps.

Application Monitor

New Run Type

Transparency matters!

Previously, all data uploads were logged under the same DATA_IMPRT run type, making it difficult to distinguish whether new data was appended or existing data was overwritten.

To improve clarity, we‚Äôve introduced a new run type: DATA_OVRWRT. üéâ

Whenever you overwrite all or filtered records in the Data Management screen, the system automatically creates a DATA_OVRWRT run in Application Monitor, complete with detailed message logs and overwrite action information.

This enhancement improves traceability and supports precise auditing of data changes.

For more details about the different run types, see Event Status and Run Types in SAP Help Portal.

System Applications

Quick Refresh for Faster Updates

The Refresh action is now available across System applications:

  • Application Monitor
  • Process Monitor
  • Comment Monitor
  • History Monitor
  • Process Scheduler

This feature allows users to refresh data without reloading the entire application, preserving layout adjustments, and improving efficiency.

That‚Äôs a Wrap! üéÅ

Ready to try these enhancements? Explore the new features and check our SAP Help Portal for detailed documentation.

Here‚Äôs to a festive season and an innovative year ahead! ü•≥

entry.title: Mastering Business Process Mapping: A Practical Playbook for 2026 and Beyond
entry.content:
Kick off 2026 with a practical session focused on one of the most essential capabilities in business transformation: business process mapping. This expert-led session will guide you through structuring and scaling your process landscape using real-world techniques and proven frameworks. From process hierarchies and folder structures to variant mapping and taxonomies, you‚Äôll learn how to build clarity and consistency into your models. We‚Äôll also explore how and when to apply SAP Signavio accelerators like Process Explorer and APQC content to support faster rollout, governance, and maturity. Whether you‚Äôre just starting your BPM journey or evolving your current modeling standards, this session is your playbook for process excellence in 2026.

Registration page: https://url.sap/cmmc4b

entry.title: Automating Vendor Tax Status & Withholding Tax Updates in SAP S/4HANA Business Partner
entry.content:
Objective:

The purpose of this custom made utility development is to automate the process of updating vendor tax statuses and corresponding withholding tax types and codes within the Business Partner (BP) master data. The update will be driven by predefined criteria maintained in a custom table and a periodic tax-status file received from external tax authorities or regulatory bodies.

The custom build utility will read tax identification numbers (such as national ID, business registration number, or equivalent) from the input file, compare them with vendor master records, determine the required changes, and automatically update the relevant tax-related fields in the system.

This is my practical exposure to deliver this utility being work as functional side to fulfill user requirements based on country specific governance and compliance.  

Process Overview

Below are the following steps will be taken to update Tax Status and Withholding Tax Codes in Business Partner master data:

  1. Pre-Requisites

Before using the utility, Following must be ensured:

  1. Business Partner must already be created.
  2. Tax payer registration number must be maintained in the BP Tax Data section.
  3. Let‚Äôs Assume we have 3 different tax authorities and with

FBR (National Tax Authority) - Filer / Non-Filer Status must be updated in Tax Data ‚Üí Tax Type field. (3 different fields you can identify for use this purpose).

Example:

    • Z1 -> Filer
    • Z2 -> Non-Filer
  1. SRB (Provincial Tax Authority) Active / Non-Active Status must be updated in Tax Data ‚Üí Industry Main Type field:

Example:

    • S1 -> Active
    • S2 -> Non-Active
  1. PRA (Provincial Tax Authority) Active / Non-Active Status must be updated in Tax Data ‚Üí Tax Declaration Type field:

Example:

    • P1 -> Active
    • P2 -> Non-Active
  1. Withholding Tax Types and Codes must already be maintained under Company Code Data in BP.
  2. Download the tax status files from FBR, SRB, and PRA, merge all NTN/CNIC values into one Notepad (.txt) file ‚Äî one row per NTN/CNIC.
  1. Custom Table ‚Äì Withholding Tax Combinations

A custom table will be created to store WHT combination rules for each tax authority i.e. (FBR IT, SRB ST, PRA ST). This table will define:

  • Which WHT Type and Code must be assigned when a vendor has status
    Z1 ‚Üí Z2, Z2 ‚Üí Z1, S1 ‚Üí S2, S2 ‚Üí S1, P1 ‚Üí P2, P2 ‚Üí P1, etc.
  • All fields in the table will use standard SAP fields with search help enabled.

Table Structure (Example):

Tax Type

WHT Type

WHT Code

New Tax Type

New WHT Type

New WHT Code

Z1

N2

WD

Z2

N2

WE

Z2

N2

WE

Z1

N2

WD

S1

WO

WK

S2

I7

W6

S2

I7

W6

S1

WO

WK

P1

IT

W2

P2

IT

W8

P2

IT

W8

P1

IT

W2

Above structure will be used for all combinations.

  1. Program Utility ‚Äì Custom Made WRICEF

Selection Screen:

Program will require the following selection criteria:

  1. Upload Notepad File (txt) containing NTN/CNIC list
  2. Select Tax Type Category for update:
    • Income Tax WHT (Z1 ‚Üî Z2, Z2 ‚Üî Z1)
    • Sales Tax WHT (S1 ‚Üî S2, S2 ‚Üî S1)
    • PRA Sales Tax WHT (P1 ‚Üî P2, P2 ‚Üî P1)

Execute to process data.

  1. System Processing Logic

Upon execution, the system will:

  1. Read all NTN/CNIC entries from the uploaded file.
  2. Compare with existing vendor master data.
  3. Determine whether status changes are required based on rules from the WHT Combinations Custom Table.
  4. Display the results in ALV format if any update is required.

ALV Output Columns:

The following fields must be displayed:

  • Vendor Code
  • Vendor Name
  • CNIC
  • NTN
  • Filer / Non-Filer Status
  • Industry Code
  • Industry Type
  • Current Status (derived on run time using uploading file):
    • Case 1: Taxpayer registration number does not exist in ATL
    • Case 2: Taxpayer registration number exists in ATL
  • Existing Status
  • Existing Status Description
  • New Status
  • New Status Description
  • Existing WHT Type
  • Existing WHT Type Description
  • Existing WHT Code
  • Existing WHT Code Description
  • New WHT Type
  • New WHT Type Description
  • New WHT Code
  • New WHT Code Description

 

  1. Update Logic

After verification:

  • User will click ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button.
  • System will update all relevant fields in the vendor Master (BP):
    • Tax Type (Filer / Non-Filer, Active / Non Active)
    • Withholding Tax Types
    • Withholding Tax Codes

The update must follow the rules defined in the custom table.

entry.title: Re: S4 Public CloudÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂÆûÁé∞‰ΩøÁî®ÊñáÊ°£Âá≠ËØÅÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂêåÊó∂Â∞ÜÂà∂ÈÄ†ÂõæÁ∫∏Á≠âÊñá‰ª∂‰øùÁïôÂú®Êú¨Âú∞
entry.content:
SAP Machine Translation Portal translation:

How S4 Public Cloud enables the use of document document capabilities while keeping files like manufacturing drawings locally

Do you have a consultant who is familiar with ECC DMS?

The German subsidiary of the Chinese customer is implementing the project to switch from ECC to S4 Public Cloud.

Existing manufacturing drawings for German subsidiary users, for example, exist in ECC via document documents, but the original file is also on the local server. A document document is a document of a flipchart file and can be used for file version management (ECC DMS).

If switching from ECC to S4 Public Cloud, the German subsidiary user wants the file not to be uploaded to S4 Public Cloud, only the document document is created, and the file is placed locally in Germany. Does S4 Public Cloud have a corresponding implementation option?

German users are aware that if they use S4 Public Cloud, they need to transfer files to S4 Public Cloud, worry about security issues, and do not want to upload them, but they want to use the document document functionality. Experts who wish to become familiar with DMS with SAP have the opportunity to communicate. Thank you very much.

entry.title: Convert XML File to Internal Table And Download Into CSV Format In ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction:
In most SAP ABAP projects, file uploads are a very common requirement‚Äîparticularly in formats like TXT, CSV, or Excel. These formats are straightforward to parse using standard approaches such as GUI_UPLOAD, CL_GUI_FRONTEND_SERVICES, or transformations.

  • However, during a recent requirement, I encountered a different scenario:
    the business team wanted to upload an XML file, extract specific fields from the XML structure, convert the values into an ABAP internal table, and finally allow users to download the processed data in CSV format.
  • While XML is widely used for integrations, parsing XML inside ABAP is not as common in day-to-day development‚Äîespecially when the XML structure is nested and needs to be converted into a flattened internal table.
    This made the requirement both interesting and challenging:
  • How do we read an XML file from the presentation server?
  • How do we parse the XML structure into an easily consumable internal table?
  • How do we convert the extracted data into a CSV file dynamically?
  • How do we present the parsed data to the user (ALV) before export?
  • SAP fortunately provides powerful XML-handling tools such as CL_XML_DOCUMENT and SMUM_XML_PARSE, which help convert XML into a tree-like format that can be processed easily. Using these, we can extract required data nodes (like EmpID, EmpName, Salary) and map them into a custom structure.

This blog explains the complete end-to-end solution:

  • Reading XML from local file
  • Parsing XML using SMUM_XML_PARSE
  • Populating an internal table
  • Displaying the result in ALV
  • Exporting the final output to CSV
  • This approach can be reused for any XML To ABAP conversion scenario, not just employee data. Whether you are processing orders, invoices, or custom data feeds, the same logic applies with minor adjustments.
" Data declarations
DATA: gcl_xml       TYPE REF TO cl_xml_document,
      gv_xml_string TYPE xstring,
      gv_size       TYPE sytabix,
      gt_xml_data   TYPE TABLE OF smum_xmltb,
      gwa_xml_data  TYPE smum_xmltb,
      gt_return     TYPE TABLE OF bapiret2.

" Employee structure
TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_employee,
         empid   TYPE char10,
         empname TYPE char50,
         salary  TYPE char15,
       END OF ty_employee.

DATA: gt_employees TYPE TABLE OF ty_employee,
      gwa_employee TYPE ty_employee.

" File parameter
PARAMETERS: p_file TYPE ibipparms-path.

" F4 help for file selection
AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_file.
  CALL FUNCTION 'F4_FILENAME'
    IMPORTING
      file_name = p_file.

START-OF-SELECTION.

  " Create XML document object
  CREATE OBJECT gcl_xml.

  " Import XML from file
  gcl_xml->import_from_file( filename = p_file ).

  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    " Render XML to xstring
    gcl_xml->render_2_xstring( IMPORTING
                               stream = gv_xml_string
                               size = gv_size ).

    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      " Parse XML
      CALL FUNCTION 'SMUM_XML_PARSE'
        EXPORTING
          xml_input = gv_xml_string
        TABLES
          xml_table = gt_xml_data
          return    = gt_return.

      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        " Process XML data to extract employee information
        LOOP AT gt_xml_data INTO gwa_xml_data.
          CASE gwa_xml_data-cname.
            WHEN 'EmpID'.
              gwa_employee-empid = gwa_xml_data-cvalue.
            WHEN 'EmpName'.
              gwa_employee-empname = gwa_xml_data-cvalue.
            WHEN 'Salary'.
              gwa_employee-salary = gwa_xml_data-cvalue.
              " Append when all fields are collected
              APPEND gwa_employee TO gt_employees.
              CLEAR gwa_employee.
          ENDCASE.
        ENDLOOP.

        " Display data using ALV
        IF gt_employees IS NOT INITIAL.
          TRY.

              CALL METHOD cl_salv_table=>factory
                IMPORTING
                  r_salv_table = data(lo_alv)
                CHANGING
                  t_table      = gt_employees.

              " Get columns object
              DATA(lo_columns) = lo_alv->get_columns( ).
              lo_columns->set_optimize( abap_true ).

              " Set column headers
              TRY.
                  DATA(lo_column) = lo_columns->get_column( columnname = 'EMPID' ).
                  lo_column->set_long_text( 'Employee ID' ).
                  lo_column->set_medium_text( 'Emp ID' ).
                  lo_column->set_short_text( 'EmpID' ).
                CATCH cx_salv_not_found.
              ENDTRY.

              TRY.
                  lo_column = lo_columns->get_column( columnname = 'EMPNAME' ).
                  lo_column->set_long_text( 'Employee Name' ).
                  lo_column->set_medium_text( 'Emp Name' ).
                  lo_column->set_short_text( 'EmpName' ).
                CATCH cx_salv_not_found.
              ENDTRY.

              TRY.
                  lo_column = lo_columns->get_column( columnname = 'SALARY' ).
                  lo_column->set_long_text( 'Employee Salary' ).
                  lo_column->set_medium_text( 'Salary' ).
                  lo_column->set_short_text( 'Salary' ).
                CATCH cx_salv_not_found.
              ENDTRY.

              " Display ALV
              lo_alv->display( ).

            CATCH cx_salv_msg.
          ENDTRY.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.

  ENDIF.
Data : IOUT          TYPE TABLE OF STRING,
      XOUT TYPE STRING.
      FIELD-SYMBOLS: <FS>.


  LOOP AT GT_EMPLOYEES INTO GWA_EMPLOYEE.

    CLEAR XOUT.
    DO.
      ASSIGN COMPONENT SY-INDEX OF STRUCTURE GWA_EMPLOYEE TO <FS>.
      IF SY-SUBRC <> 0.
        EXIT.
      ENDIF.
      IF SY-INDEX = 1.
        XOUT = <FS>.
      ELSE.
        CONCATENATE XOUT <FS> INTO XOUT SEPARATED BY ','.
      ENDIF.
    ENDDO.

    APPEND XOUT TO IOUT.

  ENDLOOP.

  CALL FUNCTION 'GUI_DOWNLOAD'
    EXPORTING
      FILENAME = 'C:- Tech_csv.csv'
    TABLES
      DATA_TAB = IOUT.

Conclusion:

This blog demonstrated a clear and practical approach to reading XML files in ABAP and transforming their contents into structured data using the Factory Method pattern. By separating file parsing, object creation, and data handling, the solution becomes more scalable, maintainable, and easy to extend for future XML formats. This design not only improves code readability but also ensures that enhancements or format changes can be accommodated with minimal impact on existing logic.

ABAP Development  
ABAP Connectivity
